text:
actually dw, I think something like this will work:
```def market_pricing_file_type(file_path: str) -> str:
    """
    Determines whether a file is BASIC, ADVANCED or PRO
    :param file_path: the filepath
    :return: the type of file {'BASIC','ADVANCED','PRO', 'UNKNOWN'}
    """

    with patch_open(file_name=file_path, read_write='rb') as f:
        for line_count, line in enumerate(f.readlines(), 1):
            if b'"batb":' in line:
                return "ADVANCED"
            if b'"atb":' in line:
                return "PRO"
        return "BASIC"```

text:
The Wall Street Journal 

Stock Pickers Are Struggling to Beat the Market

Some 85% of active U.S. stock funds were on pace to underperform the S&P 500 this year

Where should you put your betfair winnings?
It's embarrassing that stock brokers can't beat the market and charge big commissions.

text:
I think we'd all just keep compounding into Betfair as long as we can, but I expect a lot of us are hitting max capacities for our strategies pretty easily. 

My 2 cents - For excess money, dollar cost averaging into index funds is probably the right thing for most people, especially if you're saving for long horizons like over decades. I'm personally also getting more exposure to property, but that isn't entirely through choice (long story), but I also don't think it's a bad option depending on the specific investment. 

Also I think just spending it is a good idea! Within reason and in an intentional manner of course. For example I'll be doing a very extensive refurb of my house soon. It'll likely cost more than the £value I'll get back in the increased price of the house in the short term, but I'll get to live in a really nice place for the foreseeable future and have a home gym, so I think it's money well spent.

Alternatively loaning or gifting money to people who can better make use of the money is also a good choice in my opinion.

elements.text:
I think we'd all just keep compounding into Betfair as long as we can, but I expect a lot of us are hitting max capacities for our strategies pretty easily. 

My 2 cents - For excess money, dollar cost averaging into index funds is probably the right thing for most people, especially if you're saving for long horizons like over decades. I'm personally also getting more exposure to property, but that isn't entirely through choice (long story), but I also don't think it's a bad option depending on the specific investment. 

Also I think just spending it is a good idea! Within reason and in an intentional manner of course. For example I'll be doing a very extensive refurb of my house soon. It'll likely cost more than the £value I'll get back in the increased price of the house in the short term, but I'll get to live in a really nice place for the foreseeable future and have a home gym, so I think it's money well spent.

Alternatively loaning or gifting money to people who can better make use of the money is also a good choice in my opinion.

text:
In terms of index funds - I'd say just go as diversified as possible, like FTSE World tracker type thing. Don't bother trying to pick industries or regions as that's still pretty much pot luck.

In my ISA I made a few bets on specific stocks this year, and I'm up against indices, so it's easy to think I'm a fantastic portfolio manager, but the reality is that the sample size and time window is so tiny that it's just gambling. It can be fun though, which is why I've done it, but I'm thinking of being boring and sensible and converting my gains to my world tracker as well this coming year.

text: I quite like <https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/fundsoffunds.asp#:~:text=A%20fund%20of%20funds%20(FOF)%E2%80%94also%20known%20as%20a,and%20other%20types%20of%20securities.|FOF's> but also build my own portfolio from the bigger funds such as Invesco, etc. With a decent mix of low/medium/high risk funds, I get around 10%-20% return annually, which is reinvested and compounded. I don't make a life changing income from betfair, I seem to enjoy the challenge more than the £.

attachments.text: Also known as a multi-manager investment, a fund of funds (FOF) is a pooled fund that invests in other funds, usually hedge funds or mutual funds.
attachments.title: Fund of Funds (FOF) Definition

text: Which ftse tracker do you buy? I've been buying the fund from Vanguard.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Which ftse tracker do you buy? I've been buying the fund from Vanguard.

text:
Me? I invest in VWRL which tracks FTSE All-World. I also have some in VUKE which is a FTSE100 tracker - which goes against the advice I just gave about just diversifying globally. But I guess FTSE100 is a bit of a high yield / value play (again against my advice of not taking bets!). 

Ultimately just being invested in something fairly diversified is better than nothing though. But I think it's been shown that over the long term the majority of returns comes from a few specific stocks, so the risk is NOT being invested in those ones that do well, which is one reason why it's hard for most portfolio managers to beat an index by being selective.

Ultimately just being invested in something fairly diversified is better than nothing though. But I think it's been shown that over the long term the majority of returns comes from a few specific stocks, so the risk is NOT being invested in those ones that do well, which is one reason why it's hard for most portfolio managers to beat an index by being selective.

text: I agree that trackers are a great product for most people, it's what I get family and friends to buy but if you're putting quite a lot aside then I don't think it's the only game in town. The internal costs in tracker funds are not negligible and the resulting tracking errors do become significant. If you're putting away enough that your transaction costs aren't a big deal then just buying a well diversified portfolio of individual shares gets you the full return on your holdings and spares you the risk associated with some of the synthetic tracking.

If you're putting away enough that your transaction costs aren't a big deal then just buying a well diversified portfolio of individual shares gets you the full return on your holdings and spares you the risk associated with some of the synthetic tracking.

text:
I personally still worry whether the global stock market will continue to grow as it has done like in the hundreds of years in the past. I think one major driving factor of the past has just been population growth, which leads to consumption growth, which leads to economic growth - but I think we're beginning to see a slow down in population growth now. So who knows. 

I expect for hundreds of years people have always questioned whether stocks can just go up forever or not, and so far it has! So maybe this is just the same. There's too much incentive for people to want that to happen. Then again, perhaps times are changing…

text:
Ok not specific to that fund (I see other issues with that) but here's my genuinely educated take on buying contemporary art:

Buy art you like and hope you get lucky but never buy art as an investment unless you're at the very top of the market for long dead artists.

The art market is rigged against you because the value of art works is largely determined by who buys them. When a major museum or and influential collector buys an artist that artist's value goes up - but both parties know that so the artist sells his flagship pieces to the collector a deep discount and makes up the difference by selling low end works (editions and so on) to Joe Public at inflated prices.

Damien Hirst is one of the most egregious examples of this, his studio churns out endless editions of crappy paintings the depreciate like a new car, but the dynamic is the same all over the place.

The money side of the art world is completely filthy, corrupt and disgusting. Steer clear.

text: <@U010GM77S4W> the logic of that points to buying anything that isn't shares - cars, gold, whatever. If that's your aim I think you'd be better off looking for an asset class with very low costs that you understand reasonably well. The risk with an art fund is that you end up buying something very opaque with large inbuilt costs and a significant risk of corruption. If you want to buy physical assets purely for speculative value there are plenty of choices and you don't need the attendant costs of a fund. Whiskey, clocks, ceramics - whatever you like having on your mantlepiece.

text:
To be clear, masterworks is not a fund. You buy shares of individual pieces of art. 

They focus on art created since the Second World War as this has historically performed the strongest. 

If you sign up you get access to a database of art sales they have compiled so you can do independent analysis on whether you think the pieces on offer represent a good buy or not.

text:
Yeah, I'm similar. I think it partly comes with the increased wealth and the “higher stakes” I have at risk essentially. And obviously I reaaaally want to avoid having to get a desk job ever again. But maybe it's part and parcel of the analytical mind and mostly risk adverse attitudes (at least for me) that are needed to succeed at betting. 

There's only so much that can be done I think, and I just try not to overthink things otherwise it'll just consume my life for the worse.

text: I've been fairly lucky over the last few decades, where I've managed to cash out all my investments just before, or at the beginning of, a recession. I've then reinvested when the economy seemed to be recovering. The base rate interest is a good indication of where it's going. Obviously money sat in a bank account isn't earning as much as it could be, however it's not losing either. The interest rates are higher during a recession, so great for savers but not for borrowers. The other option is to setup regular payments into managed funds, which over the long term levels the rollercoaster.

elements.text: I've been fairly lucky over the last few decades, where I've managed to cash out all my investments just before, or at the beginning of, a recession. I've then reinvested when the economy seemed to be recovering. The base rate interest is a good indication of where it's going. Obviously money sat in a bank account isn't earning as much as it could be, however it's not losing either. The interest rates are higher during a recession, so great for savers but not for borrowers. The other option is to setup regular payments into managed funds, which over the long term levels the rollercoaster.

text:
Haha - yeah fully agree <@USYQKE5HN> except that I don't think I (we?) have more at stake, less so really. At one time I couldn't pay my rent so the roof over my head was at stake. It's not now.

I think it's the opposite really, you don't have space to think about economic melt down when you can't pay the gas bill. Basically I've transitioned from just trying to get by to defending/entrenching my privilege. The latter condition is way less stressful.

Whilst I do think about financial risks I don't want to over state it because I'm basically quite care free. Trying to set your life up such that you never have to work come what may is one of a few first world problems that I think I can endure.
